Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: GSE/EXT: Expanding the Pool Local Cooperatives for Recruiting and Retaining Women in Disciplines with Least Women

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit: The University of Colorado at Boulder, in collaboration with the University of Texas at Austin, the University of Virginia, and the University of Washington are supporting an extension service project that is synergistically serving the disciplines most in need of help for improving women?s representation: computer science, computer engineering, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering. At each of 30 institutions, interdepartmental teams of change agents from computer science, computer engineering, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering departments are being established. In each institution, high-level administrative commitment is elicited. At each ?client? institution, the interdepartmental teams recruit cooperatively for ?net new women,? as opposed to raiding each other?s pool of potential majors. Each department is adopting research-based methods for retaining undergraduate women, such as improved faculty-student interaction, and will be held accountable for initiatives, evaluation, and reporting. Cooperative department teams are supported and guided by a cadre of highly trained and experienced consultants. These train their assigned interdisciplinary teams on proven practices and methods for recruiting and retaining women. In addition, experienced staff and external evaluators will support departments and consultants with tracking and evaluation tools, collect and review periodic progress reports, and recommend improvements. This extension service focuses on reforming departmental and faculty practices in sustainable ways for long-term improvement in their undergraduate gender balance.

Broader Impacts: The project will significantly raise the number of women of all races and ethnicities who receive bachelor?s degrees in the neediest fields: computer science, computer engineering, electrical engineering, and mechanical engineering. Explicitly including minority-serving institutions will help to meet national diversity goals in these areas. Use of data to identify minority women?s typical major choices will support local recruiting on each campus. The project will bring explicit, widespread attention to the exemplar institutions and document their approaches so that others may emulate their practices.

ProgramElement.Text: RES ON GENDER IN SCI & ENGINE

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the National Center for Women & Information Technology (NCWIT) Extension Services for Undergraduate Programs (ES-UP) Expanding the Pool project was to guide and support the efforts of two cohorts of 15 teams of college/university departments in attracting and retaining undergraduate women in Computer Science, Computer Engineering, Electrical Engineering, and Mechanical Engineering departments that have poor representation of women.

The ES-UP provided customized consultation to 30 collaborative, interdisciplinary computing and engineering teams on each client campus to expand the pool of women students who apply to, enroll in, and graduate from their majors. Our approach to accomplish this goal included: 1) client departments working together to increase their pool of potential women students, instead of raiding each other's limited numbers 2) client teams collaboratively creating and implementing strategic recruiting plans and adoption of a minimum of two retention strategies, 3) departments providing data on the number of students who apply, are accepted, enroll, are retained, and graduate from their programs, and 4) clients formally reporting outcomes of recruiting and retention activities.

NCWIT ES-UP works to accomplish our objectives through numerous activities. In broad categories, they include:

  1. Creation of a knowledge base concerning organizational reform and building methodological and theoretical infrastructure to support action: ES-UP has created and disseminated many research-based resources, including our theoretical model of systemic change, recruiting and retaining workbooks, the Tracking Tool, the Entry Survey, and ES-UP website.
  2. National distribution and dissemination of the knowledge base for implementing reform: ES-UP clients, ES Consultants, and staff have presented at recruiting workshops, SIGCSE Conferences, Regional Women in Computing Conferences, Grace Hopper, Snowbird, ASEE Conferences, and various universities, directly impacting 7,700 people, and indirectly influencing 25,000 people. In addition, we have distributed 195,565 resources to clients and other individuals at various events.
  3. Implementation of Extension Services: With the goal of increasing women's representation and retention of computing and engineering students, clients and our consultants implemented the following processes: Client Site Visits, use of the Tracking Tool, developing Strategic Recruiting and Retention Plans, submission of Mini-Grant Applications, administration of Entry Surveys, and Client Final Reports.

The Extension Services project was successful in creating change in our client departments through the use of collaborative teams of computing and engineering faculty and staff who worked together to expand the pool of diverse women students who apply to, enroll in, and graduate from their degree programs. The project has made an impact on the recruitment and retention of women in computing and engineering degrees. Some specific outcomes include:

  • From 2012 to 2017, women's applications increased from 13.6% to 18.1% at participating programs that provided data.
  • From before institutions joined ES (2012) to the last year's data submitted (2016 or 2017), the number of female declared majors in computing and engineering (N=78 programs) increased 80% (from 3,182 to 5,719), while the number of male declared majors increased 45% (from 22,345 to 32,490). This difference was statistically significant.
  • In 91 programs, the number of female graduated students more than doubled (from 557 to 1,306), while the number of male graduated students increased 83% (from 3,964 to 7,239) from 2012 to the last year's data submitted (2016 or 2017). This difference was statistically significant.
  • The percentage of female declared majors increased from 12% to 15% and the percentage of female graduated students also increased from 12% to 15% after participation as an ES client. These two percentage increases were statistically significant at the p < .05 level based on the paired-samples t-test analysis.

According to the NCWIT ES external evaluator, the data provided by Extension Services supports the view that the program has had a strong impact on client institutions. In particular, the analysis of change over time from the year before ES participation to the most recent year's data suggests that the growth rate of women in ES schools is significantly stronger than the growth rate of men, with respect to declared majors and graduation rates. This growth rate statistic is important because the field of computer science has been growing as a field in the last 10 years, and showing that women are growing at a faster rate than men suggests that real change is happening.

Adoption of Recruiting and Retention Interventions

Using Dedoose qualitative software, the ES project created a database of activities from each collaborative team and evaluated clients' recruitment plans, retention strategies, their mini-grant activities progress, client survey results, and activities and outcomes from final reports. View the image for systemic change interventions that were most impactful in increasing recruitment and/or retention.

Modified by: Elizabeth Litzler

  • NCWIT Extension Services' Client Adoption of Recruiting and Retention Interventions. Interventions are described in the areas of: Retain with pedagogy, Retain with curriculum, Recruit strategically, Support initiatives, Retain with student support, and Assess efforts.

    NCWIT ES Client Adoption of Interventions
